import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory
source.0f9df666:
# Number of Athletes from Countries all around the world
fig = px.bar(Athletes, x ="NOC", title = 'Number of Athletes from Countries')
fig.show()
source.a39ce7d9:
# Maximum Athletes are from USA
Athletes['NOC'].value_counts()
source.965769b2:
# The number of Athletes from each country
Athletes_Country = Athletes_Country.sort_values('Discipline', ascending = False)
Athletes_Country.head(10)
source.952e4379:
# The Top 30 Countries with maximum Athletes
Country_Top = Athletes_Country.head(30)
Country_Top
source.c7a832c3:
# Plotting the Top 30 countries
plt.figure()
sns.set(rc = None)
plt.figure(figsize=(20,10))
sns.barplot(x=Country_Top['NOC'], 
            y=Country_Top['Discipline'], 
            linewidth = 2,
            palette = sns.color_palette("colorblind", 
            n_colors=30))
plt.xticks(rotation = 90)
plt.xlabel('Top 30 countries', fontsize = 20)
plt.ylabel('Count', fontsize = 20)
plt.title('Number of athletes by country', fontsize = 20)
plt.show()

plt.figure(figsize=(10,10))
sns.set(rc = None)
sns.barplot(Gender['Total'],Gender['Discipline']
            ,palette = sns.color_palette("dark", 
            n_colors=30),linewidth = 2)
plt.title('Maximum number of Athletes in different Events', fontsize = 15)
plt.show()
source.5547c54f:
# The maximum male participants are from Athletics
plt.figure(figsize=(10,10))
sns.set(rc = {'axes.facecolor': 'black', 'axes.grid': False,})
sns.barplot(Gender['Male'],Gender['Discipline'],)
plt.title('Male participants in different Events', fontsize = 15)
plt.show()
source.f035fbbd:

sns.set(rc = {'axes.facecolor': 'black', 'axes.grid': False,})

source.4d7d50c4:
# Comparing total number of male anf female participants 
plt.figure(figsize=(8,5))
sns.set(rc = {'axes.facecolor': '#00afff', 'axes.grid': True,})
sns.lineplot(data = Gender['Male'], linewidth = 3
             ,label = 'Male', color = 'orange')
sns.lineplot(data = Gender['Female'], linewidth = 4
             ,label = 'Female', color = 'white')
plt.title('Comparing Total Male and Female Participants')
plt.show()
source.286bacce:
# There is a opposite relation between total and rank
plt.figure(figsize = (20,7))
sns.set(rc = {'axes.facecolor': 'cyan', 'axes.grid': True,})
sns.lineplot(data = Medals_Rank['Total'], linewidth = 3
             ,label = 'Total', color = 'red', markers = True)
sns.lineplot(data =  Medals_Rank['Rank by Total'], linewidth = 3
             ,label = 'Rank', color = 'black', markers= True)
plt.title('Total and Rank', fontsize = 20)
plt.show()
source.f5351eec:
# Plotting the Countries according to the ranks-
plt.figure(figsize=(10,10))
sns.set(rc = None)
sns.barplot(Medals_Rank['Rank by Total'],Medals_Rank['Team/NOC'],
            palette = sns.color_palette("bright", 
            n_colors=30), linewidth = 2)
plt.title('Top 50 Countries and Ranks', fontsize = 15)
plt.show()
source.8820158f:
# We can drop the rank column as it is same as serial number
Medals.drop(columns = 'Rank',inplace=True)
source.0b86b4b6:
Medals_Pie = Medals.head(10)
plt.figure(figsize=[15,15])
plt.pie(Medals_Pie['Total'], labels = Medals_Pie['Team/NOC'],shadow = True, )
plt.title('Countries and Medals', fontsize = 20)
plt.show()

source.3d21c49f: # Let us first explore the Athletes dataset
source.bd8e8694:
### In this notebook, I have explored the Tokyo Olympics Dataset.
 ### Majorly the Medals, Gender and Athletes datasets and used various visualisation techniques using plotly express, seaborn and matplotlib to demonstrate various aspects in a simple way. 
 ### I wanted to both improve myself and make easier examples for those who are just at the beginning, like me.
source.bb04c959: # Now lets check if we get any interesting insights from Medals Dataset!
